0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• End stage renal disease - Hyperphosphatemia: initial, 1500 mg ORALLY per day in divided doses with meals, then titrate in increments of 750 mg/day at intervals of 2 to 3 weeks
  • End stage renal disease - Hyperphosphatemia: maintenance, 1500 to 3000 mg ORALLY per day in divided doses with meals

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: use in pediatric patients is not recommended

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: bowel obstruction, ileus, or fecal impaction

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- gastrointestinal obstruction, ileus, and fecal impaction, including serious cases requiring surgery or hospitalization, have been reported
  • -- altered gastrointestinal anatomy (eg, prior gastrointestinal surgery, colon cancer); increased risk for bowel obstruction, ileus, or fecal impaction
  • -- hypomotility disorders (eg, constipation, ileus, diabetes); increased risk for bowel obstruction, ileus, or fecal impaction
  • Other:
  • -- abdominal X-rays may have a radio-opaque appearance similar to an imaging agent

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain (5%), Diarrhea, Nausea (11%.), Vomiting (9%.)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Vascular graft occlusion, Dialysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction, Fecal impaction, Gastrointestinal obstruction

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Lanthanum carbonate reduces serum phosphate in patients with ESRD. It inhibits the absorption of dietary phosphate by forming highly insoluble lanthanum phosphate complexes.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Bioavailability, Oral: less than 0.002%
  • Effect of food:. Negligible when given during or 30 minutes after a meal; not recommended to be used with enteral nutrition

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: Not metabolized; not a substrate of CYP450

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
  • Chewable tablets: Chew completely or crush tablets to aid chewing before swallowing; do not swallow intact tablets
  • Oral powder: Sprinkle on applesauce or other soft food and administer immediately; do not premix future doses or open packet in advance; do not attempt to mix with liquids as powder is insoluble
  • for patients with poor dentition, consider use of oral powder
  • take with or immediately after meals

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: serum phosphate level; as needed during titration, regularly after target concentration achieved (ie, less than 6 mg/dL)

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
Fosrenol
  • Oral Powder: 750 MG, 1000 MG
  • Oral Tablet, Chewable: 500 MG, 750 MG, 1000 MG

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise patient to report symptoms of gastrointestinal obstruction, ileus, or fecal impaction.
  • Side effects may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, or vomiting.
  • Tell patient to alert physician prior to an abdominal x-ray that drug is being used, as drug is radio-opaque.
  • Advise patient to take with or immediately after food.
  • Instruct patient to thoroughly chew or crush tablet prior to swallowing.
  • Direct patient to sprinkle oral powder on a small amount of applesauce or similar food and consume immediately. Do not mix with liquids.
